Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: OBS survey of Kilauea's submarine south flank following the May 4, 2018 M6.9 earthquake and Lower East Rift Zone eruption
Award.AbstractNarration:
In April 2018, a dramatic shift took place in the ongoing eruption of Kilauea volcano. Both the summit lava lake and the vent at Puu Oo, active for 35 years, catastrophically drained, sending magma to the Lower East Rift Zone where it began to erupt, and eventually to flow into the ocean. This project is to deploy a network of 12 ocean-bottom seismometers to record earthquakes associated with the ongoing eruption. The instruments will be deployed on the south flank, and will record several hundred offshore earthquakes and thousands more occurring beneath Hawaii Island. The earthquake locations will aid in understanding deformation on the submarine south flank of the volcano, and provide insight into properties of the fault zone along which Kilauea Volcano moves across the Pacific plate. Recordings of the energy generated at the ocean entry where lava enters the ocean will be used to understand submarine eruptive processes such as lava-water explosions, submarine lava flows, and landslides. This project will enhance understanding of the seismic and volcanic hazards associated with eruptions from Kilauea Volcano, including possible offshore landslides and potential tsunamis. The project supports the training of students on a research expedition. The data will be made available immediately upon collection.


At Kilauea Volcano the change in eruptive activity in Spring 2018 was accompanied by an increase in seismicity within the rift zone, at the summit, and beneath the submarine south flank of the volcano. Activity has also been recorded at the margins of the submarine south flank, in areas that have not seen significant seismicity in the past. Earthquakes that have been recorded offshore are poorly located because the seismic network is limited to one half of the focal sphere. This work will focus on answering several key questions. What structures within and beneath the mobile south flank are active today, what are the deformation mechanisms associated with them, and how do they relate to the ongoing eruptions? The M 6.9 earthquake appears to have also ruptured an area that experiences aseismic slip although the interpreted slow-slip source region has far fewer aftershocks than the adjacent regions. What caused the region to slip co-seismically? Much of the submarine south flank of Kilauea is composed of fragmental lava that has been transported downslope through landsliding. How does this process evolve as a new ocean entry develops?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 eruption of Kīlauea Volcano was accompanied by processes that impacted the volcano's submarine south flank. Perhaps most dramatically, a M6.9 earthquake near the coastline shifted the flank southward and generated aftershocks beneath much of the flank. Furthermore, approximately 60% of lava erupted during the event was emplaced offshore, generating 875 acres of new land and permanently changing the island's coastline. 

The intellectual merit of this proposal centered on using ocean-bottom seismic data to better understand the effect of these processes on the stability and structure of the south flank. This RAPID proposal only supported instrument deployment and recovery, not data analysis; outcomes therefore focus on the collection of these data.  

In July 2018 we deployed a network of 12 ocean-bottom seismometers on the Kilauea south flank. Eleven instruments were recovered in September 2018; one OBS failed to return to the surface and was lost on the seafloor.  Of these instruments, 10 provided usable data, as one failed to record. Instruments were position to capture three processes:  (1) aftershocks from the M6.9, (2) seismicity related to deformation of the flank, including its outer bench, and (3) lava-water interactions at the ocean entry.  Each instrument continuously recorded both seismic and hydroacoustic data. The seismic data contain a substantial amount of noise, including a strong episodic 6 Hz hum and occasional harmonic signals. These sounds do not correlate between instruments and thus are thought to be due to instrument noise rather than a volcanic source. 

Review of the seismic and acoustic data is just beginning (this proposal supported data collection only), but preliminary analysis suggests that thousands of earthquakes were recorded, hundreds of which took place beneath the south flank. Other signals recorded by the OBS network include the sounds of lava-water interaction along the Puna coast. These signals include explosive events, tremor that may be associated with offshore lava flows, and submarine landslides. 

The broader impacts of this proposal included the sharing of these data with other users, including staff at the USGS Hawaiian Volcano Observatory. To this end, data have been uploaded to the IRIS data center with no restrictions on data access. In the spirit of sharing this unique opportunity, we also invited scientists from the University of Hawai`i to join the cruise to collect chlorophyll data during our off hours. 

A second important impact of this project involved student training. Seven students (four graduate students and three undergraduates) from four universities participated in the research cruise. These students gained experience constructing and deploying OBS, and they monitored the ship multibeam system during mapping periods. Students also helped collect CTD data, launched XBTs, and learned basic marine operations.
